Below is an infographic of the school reopening metric, generated by state officials. It includes 5 benchmarks. In Little Compton, this metric is our True North, as we all work together to navigate through the planning process for the new school year.

Statewide Readiness: Does the state-level data indicate the state should be in phase three or higher?

Municipal Readiness: Do municipal-level case incidence rate indicate it’s safe to fully reopen?

Testing Readiness: Do we have the ability to test all symptomatic staff and students and on average get results within 48 to 72 hours?

Supply Readiness: Does every school have more than sufficient cleaning supplies, soap and hand sanitizer, and face masks?

Operational Readiness: Does every district have a plan that has been vetted by the Rhode Island Department of Education and the Rhode Island Department of Health?

Laurie

Ms. Vareika and Mrs. Connolly attended a Smithsonian Workshop last June. The two educators realized the beauty of teaching in a K - 8th-grade school allows for middle schoolers and kindergarteners to work together -- benefiting all!

Last week, they completed their culminating activity of a mini unit: "Looking at Little Compton" and applying the five themes of geography. 7th Grade shared their investigation as teachers with the K students. The 7th graders worked with their buddies on the writing process of revising and editing their posters (below pics). The 7th graders then collaborated with their buddies in creating postcards about their hometown of Little Compton. It was AMAZING to see the bonding that took place!

A team of educators from Wilbur & McMahon School recently participated (10/10/2019 &10/24/2019) in Recess Rocks in RI training. Playworks conducted the training - the workshop goals were to:
* Identify games and strategies for implementing play at recess
* Identify three lenses for assessing the quality of recess using the Great Recess Framework (GRF)
* Develop a recess design for their site that aligns with the GRF/Recess Indicators
* Develop an action plan to implement the recess design

Participating in the training were Teacher Assistants - Joshua Guay, Marjorie Harnedy, Allison Morgan, Beth Turcotte, and Carla Woodhouse; Physical Education/Health Teachers - Jason Ford and Noelle Kiernan and Principal - Sonya Whipp.

This team will meet monthly to review recess protocols at WMS and share with you our progress. The training was sponsored by: Blue Cross Blue Shield of RI, Playworks and RI Healthy Schools Coalition.

A warm poem on a wintry day....

"Hot Chocolate"

Of all the world’s concoctions
and culinary invention
it is hot chocolate
that’s worth the mention.

Chocolate caliente
and
santafereño,
forró csokoládé
and
cioccolato caldo.

The universal languages
of music, of art,
are each eclipsed
when the chocolate is hot.

Drink the rich sweetness,
the chocolate chaud,
with a dash of milk,
or a fluffy marshmallow.

The Earth is a bowl,
wrapped in meridians,
filled with hot chocolate,
for all the world’s citizens!

-Laurie Dias-Mitchell

The Hour of Code started as a one-hour introduction to computer science, designed to demystify "code", to show that anybody can learn the basics, and to broaden participation in the field of computer science. It has since become a worldwide effort to celebrate computer science, starting with 1-hour coding activities but expanding to all sorts of community efforts. This grassroots campaign is supported by over 400 partners and 200,000 educators worldwide.

The Hour of Code takes place each year during Computer Science Education Week. The 2018 Computer Science Education Week will be December 3-9, 2018.

post_text: Grade 5 worked with the Lloyd Center to explore watersheds. The Lloyd Center demonstrated how point source pollution (like run-off from roads, farms, industry and other sources) cause pollution in the running and standing bodies of water using an Enviroscape model. They also showed how water flows underground, how it is filtered by sand and soil and how a point source pollutant can be traced back to the original source through a groundwater flow model. Thanks go to the Sogkonate Garden Club for providing this opportunity to the students.
